title: ASX to rise, Wall St stumbles, gold loses lustre
summary: Australian shares are poised to open higher, despite weakness on Wall Street and in oil, iron ore and gold. $A slips on rising $US. Bitcoin eyes $US60,000.

title: ASX to open higher as JobKeeper ends
summary: Australian shares are set to rise as markets lifted before a shortened Easter week and investors looked to the end of pandemic unemployment benefits.

title: ASX to open higher as Nasdaq stays low
summary: Australian shares are set to open flat as tech stocks continued to slump despite forecasts of stronger growth in the US economy.
text: {'heading': ['Australian shares are set to open higher as tech stocks continued to slump despite forecasts of stronger growth in the US economy.', 'The Nasdaq led Wall Street lower as a rotation out of richly valued stocks into underpriced sectors added to pressure from quarter-end rebalancing by institutional investors.', 'US President Joe Biden, in his first White House press conference, said the economic outlook is brightening thanks to the recent passage of his $US1.9 trillion pandemic relief package, and a majority of economists now expect growth this year to exceed 6 per cent.', '“Since we passed the American Rescue Plan, we’re starting to see new signs of hope in our economy,” Biden said during his first press conference since taking office in January.', '“Since it was passed, a majority ... of economic forecasters have significantly increased their projections on the economic growth that’s going to take place this year. They’re now projecting it will exceed 6 per cent growth in GDP (gross domestic product).”', 'Federal Reserve Vice Chair Richard Clarida said the US economic recovery remains incomplete, even as the central bank forecasts stronger growth ahead.', '“It will take some time for economic activity and employment to return to levels that prevailed at the business cycle peak reached last February,” Clarida said Thursday in remarks prepared for a virtual event hosted by the Institute of International Finance. “We are committed to using our full range of tools to support the economy until the job is well and truly done to help ensure that the economic recovery will be as robust and rapid as possible.”', 'Initial claims for US state unemployment benefits fell last week to 657,000, a decrease of 100,000 from the previous week, the Labor Department reported Thursday. The pan-European STOXX 600 index slipped 0.3 per cent, weighed down by a drop in oil and gas stocks on the back of weaker crude prices, and bank stocks as bond yields declined.', 'The benchmark index pulled back from 13-month highs last week as a new wave of coronavirus infection and a fresh regional lockdowns overshadowed a surprisingly strong recovery in March business activity.', 'Stocks in London underperformed their regional peers as the European Union mulled the possibility of blocking shipments to countries with higher inoculation rates such as Britain, or which are not sharing doses they produce.'], 'Asia': ['Tech giants from Tencent Holdings to Alibaba Group Holding dived after US regulators revived threats to toss China’s largest corporations off US bourses, compounding concerns of a widening domestic antitrust crackdown.', 'Alibaba slid almost 4 per cent in Hong Kong Thursday, joining a US sell-off that wiped at least 20 per cent off Chinese tech names including Tencent Music Entertainment and iQiyi, Baidu’s Netflix-like streaming subsidiary. Food delivery giant Meituan, which reports 2020 results Friday, shed 1.6 per cent. The losses followed a warning from the Securities and Exchange Commission that it’s taking steps to force accounting firms to let US regulators review the financial audits of overseas companies -- the penalty for noncompliance being ejection from exchanges.'], 'Currencies': ['The US dollar reached a fresh four-month high before slashing its gains on Thursday, as yields on US Treasuries dipped and investors’ appetite for risk shrunk.', 'The dollar index was mostly unchanged at 92.6410 in mid-morning trading. Yields on Treasuries crept down and stocks fell, with 10-year notes yielding 1.598 ahead of an auction on shorter-dated bonds on Thursday.', '“AUD-USD rallies have been contained over the past 24 hours after the Aussie broke resistance earlier in the week. Broad US dollar demand and deteriorating risk sentiment continue to weigh on the pair. Rising US yields and an underlying feel of de-risking elsewhere are keeping AUD-USD choppy and under duress,” writes Stephen Innes from Axi.'], 'Commodities': ['LPL Financial says commodity markets have roared back as the global economy has emerged from the shadow of COVID-19 since March 23 last year. Oil and lumber prices have more than doubled off the lows, while copper prices have pulled back a bit after reaching that feat back in February', '“After likely their worst period in history, although I wasn’t around for the bubonic plague so I can’t be certain, commodity prices have roared back as the global economy continues to wake up,” added LPL Financial Chief Market Strategist Ryan Detrick.', '“The US and China are well ahead of other nations in terms of economy activity and output, so as the rest of the world plays catch up, we wouldn’t be surprised to see commodities rise even further.”'], 'Australian sharemarket': ['The Australian sharemarket ended the day with gains, as healthcare companies and banks helped the market to its third gain in four sessions, offsetting losses for AMP, Afterpay and exchange operator ASX.', 'The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.2 per cent, or 11 points, to 6790.6.', 'The gains defied a weak lead from the US, where stocks ended lower after an optimistic outlook from US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell and Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen wasn’t enough to offset a slide in tech stocks.', 'Tech stocks were similarly weak in Australian trading, with Afterpay falling to its lowest level since December during the session before ending the day down 1.9 per cent at $105.46. Xero dropped 1.1 per cent to $122.17 and Zip fell 5.3 per cent to $7.53.']}
author: Natasha Rudra

title: ASX to slip as US tech stocks fall

title: ASX to open flat despite unsettled US markets
summary: Australian shares are set to open flat after choppy trading on Wall Street, while Jerome Powell and Janet Yellen told Congress the US economy was still vulnerable to the pandemic.
text: {'heading': ['Australian shares are set to open flat after choppy trading on Wall Street, while Jerome Powell and Janet Yellen told Congress the US economy was still vulnerable to the pandemic.', 'Making their first joint appearance in their current jobs, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said more must be done to limit the damage from the coronavirus pandemic and to promote a full economic recovery.', 'Powell testified that a recovery is far from complete, so the Fed will “continue to provide the economy the support it needs for as long as it takes.”', 'Oil and gas prices slid while travel-related stocks fell as much as 4 per cent.', '“The stock market is facing several tailwinds, including the recent passage of additional fiscal stimulus, the faster pace of COVID-19 vaccinations and consumers holding plenty of cash that was saved during the COVID-19-related lockdowns from last year,” writes Greg Marcus, managing director of UBS Private Wealth Management.', '“We think there is more room for the stock market to run, as the economy continues to reopen.', '“While the rise in bond yields has caused stock market volatility in recent weeks, we believe the uptick in yields is simply part of the reflation trade. All other asset classes have either hit their pre-pandemic levels or exceeded them, with the exception of the 10-year Treasury bond. Bond yields are simply returning to pre-pandemic levels, which were already very low by historical comparisons. We expect the broader stock market to be able to cope with higher bond yields.', '“The one area of the stock market that I am concerned about in the face of rising bond yields are technology stocks trading at high price-to-sales multiples. title: ASX to open slightly lower as Wall St marks anniversary of virus crash
summary: Australian shares are set to drop slightly exactly a year after the US pandemic sharemarket plunge that eventually turned into a roaring bull market.
text: {'heading': ['Australian shares are set to drop slightly as Wall Street marks the one-year anniversary of the pandemic share crash.', 'It was one year ago that the terrifying free fall for the sharemarket suddenly ended, ushering in one of its greatest runs.', 'On March 23, 2020, the S&P 500 fell 2.9 per cent. In all, the index dropped nearly 34 per cent in about a month, wiping out three years’ worth of gains for the market.', 'That turned out to be the bottom, even though the coronavirus pandemic worsened in the ensuing months and the economy sank deeper into recession. Massive amounts of support for the economy from the Federal Reserve and Congress limited how far stocks would fall. The market recovered all its losses by August.', 'As time passed, the quick development of coronavirus vaccines helped stocks shoot even higher. So did growing legions of first-time investors, who suddenly had plenty of time to get into the market using free trading apps on their phones.', 'It all led to a roughly 75 per cent surge for the S&P 500 over the last 12 months and a shocking return to record heights, especially considering that over the last 50 calendar years, the median gain for the index has been 12.4 per cent.', 'One symbol of the resurgence is Elon Musk’s Telsa, which jumped over 6 per cent on the back of a bullish report from Ark Invest, the influential shareholder in the electric car maker.', 'Ark Invest said in a report on Friday it expects Tesla’s stock price to more than quadruple to $US3000 by 2025. While the Australian dollar’s appreciation has cut into local prices to some extent, Australian grain is now well priced in key southeast Asian export markets due to a steep rise in global shipping costs – a stark reversal from just two seasons ago. The dollar index fell about 0.25 per cent at 91.86, following last week’s gain of 0.5 per cent.', 'Over the weekend, Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan’s shock replacement of a hawkish central bank governor with a critic of high interest rates dragged the lira down as much as 15 per cent to 8.485 against the dollar.', 'Euro zone government bond yields eased.', 'German bond yields were also under downward pressure as concerns about rising COVID-19 cases in the euro area encouraged investors to bet that the European Central Bank will want to keep rates as low as possible.', 'Francoise Huang, senior economist at Euler Hermes, declares Chinese stimulus will not be saving the global economy this time round. “Authorities in China are describing the policy mix in 2021 as ‘proactive’ on the fiscal side, and ‘prudent’ on the monetary side.', '“However, China’s monetary policy already started to tighten in Q4 2020, going starkly in the opposite direction compared to the world’s other major economies.”'], 'Commodities': ['Neil Shearing, group chief economist at Capital Economics, says the commodities supercycle won’t be playing a role in inflation’s return. He writes there have been three commodities supercycles in the past 130 years - linked to US industrialisation, post-World War II rebuilding, and China’s boom in the 90s. “One thing that all these episodes had in common is that they were framed by a simple narrative that explained the initial rise in prices and built expectations of further increases in the future. This helps to sustain the initial upswing of the cycle,” he writes.', '“The narrative of a new supercycle is built around the green economy. Electric vehicles use three times more copper per unit than their conventional (fossil-fuelled) counterparts. The immediate effect of a surge in green investment would therefore be to boost demand for a whole range of commodities, thus setting the stage for a new supercycle.', '“In reality, however, we suspect the drivers of commodity prices over the next couple of years will be more mundane. China remains the dominant player in industrial metals. It accounts for roughly half of the global consumption of most industrial metals.', '“Unsurprisingly, there is a strong correlation between our proprietary measure of economic growth in China and shifts in industrial metals prices. As I argued last week, we expect China’s economy to slow over the next year as pre-pandemic problems resurface. And we expect the price of most industrial metals to fall with it.”'], 'Australian sharemarket': ['The Australian sharemarket gained ground on Monday, ending a three-session losing streak driven by gains for energy and utility companies.', 'The S&P/ASX 200 rose 44 points to trade 0.7 per cent higher at 6752 points, while the All Ordinaries benchmark rose 35 points to 6995 points for a gain of 0.5 per cent.', 'The day was marked by a tumultuous return to the stock market for Freedom Foods, the Australian UHT milk and cereal producer. The stock fell 82 per cent on Monday to $US0.53 in its first day of trading after a nine-month hiatus.', 'The fall in stock price wiped hundreds of millions of dollars in the company’s market value and came after the business announced last week a plan to raise up to $US265 million to help reduce debt.']}

text: {'heading': ['Australian shares are likely to open lower as markets lost ground in the aftermath of a big week.', 'It’s a quiet week coming up for economic data in Australia and New Zealand with IHS Markit PMI data the main events.', '“Analysts are likely to reflect on the very strong employment figures and what it means for the outlook. Adding to the vacuum is a notable absence of any scheduled RBA speak between now and the next board meeting on April 6.', '“As for data, there is the Markit PMIs and Preliminary Merchandise Trade on Tuesday, neither expected to be market moving,” writes Taylor Nugent, economist at NAB Markets Research.', '“In the sample of PMIs that arrive next week, it will probably remain the case that only the US and Australia are registering economic growth during the first quarter of the year and in that order by way of magnitudes,” writes Derek Holt, vice-president and head of capital markets economics at Scotia Economics.', '“Global markets will continue to price an inflection point in the world economy that is bringing with it less synchronous policy developments and greater scope for differentiation across market outcomes. Evidence of this development takes the form of diverging central bank actions which is not terribly unusual to see during the nascent stages of emerging from a global crisis.', '“The Fed, for example, has clearly telegraphed it supports steeper sovereign bond yield curves and has been both passively enabling higher yields and actively encouraging this with upbeat forecasts and through ending the Supplementary Leverage Ratio’s exclusion of Treasuries and reserves from the definition of assets against which capital must be held.', '“The full aftermath of the SLR decision and the related move to raise reverse repo counter-party limits to US$80 billion will require time to evaluate through a coming surge in bank reserves and broad liquidity.”', 'The Federal Reserve says it will restore capital requirements for large banks that were relaxed as part of the Fed’s efforts to shore up the financial system during the early days of the pandemic.', 'The Fed said it will not extend the relief from what is called the supplementary leverage ratio past March 31. The easing of the regulation had been intended to give banks flexibility in what assets they could hold to meet regulatory’ requirements during the turmoil of the pandemic, when banks were having to suddenly write down billions of dollars of loans.'], "Today's agenda": ['Local: none', 'Overseas data: US Chicago Fed Nat Act index; US existing home sales February.'], 'Market highlights': ['ASX futures down 15 points or -0.2% to 6661', 'AUD flat to 77.38 US cents', 'Bitcoin on bitstamp.net $US58,712.27', 'On Wall St: Dow -0.7% S&P 500 -0.1% Nasdaq +0.8%', 'In Europe: Stoxx 50 -0.8% FTSE -1% DAX -1% CAC -1.1%', 'In New York: BHP -1.5% Rio -1.3% Atlassian -0.1%', 'Spot gold +0.5% to $US1745.23 an ounce', 'Brent crude +2% to $US64.53 a barrel', 'US oil +2.4% to $US61.42 a barrel', 'Iron ore -3.1% to $US161.39 a tonne', '2-year yield: US 0.15% Australia 0.08%', '5-year yield: US 0.88% Australia 0.92%', '10-year yield: US 1.72% Australia 1.80% Germany -0.30%'], "From today's Financial Review": ['Deluge wreaks havoc across NSW: Businesses in NSW already battered by the pandemic are bracing for another hit, as insurers prepare for a surge in claims and the government offers financial assistance.', 'ASX failure delays Airtasker listing: The latest blunder comes after a technical glitch in November forced an embarrassing shutdown of Australia’s primary equity capital markets.', 'Companies shun $4b JobMaker, force changes: The chief executives of some of Australia’s largest companies haven’t taken up the government’s $4 billion job-hiring program.', 'Read today’s paper, exactly as it was printed, here'], 'United States': ['The Nasdaq ended higher on Friday, lifted by Facebook and energy shares, while the S&P 500 lost ground as US Treasury yields took a break from a recent surge.', 'Reversing a recent trend, so-called growth stocks mostly outperformed value stocks viewed as likely to benefit most as the economy recovers from the coronavirus pandemic.', 'Vito J. Chinese H-shares listed in Hong Kong fell 1.71 per cent, while the Hang Seng Index was down 1.55 per cent.', '“Mainland China and Hong Kong markets are following the global sell-off after the bond yield jumped overnight,” said Linus Yip, a strategist at First Shanghai Securities.', '“The weak turnover in both markets show investors are cautious. Sell-offs in high-valuation stocks including tech continues, which is in line with a global trend.”'], 'Currencies': ['The dollar advanced against major currencies, hitting a more than one-week high. Since early January, the dollar index, a gauge of its value against six major currencies, has gained about 3.3 per cent, with the benchmark US 10-year note climbing about 80 basis points in the same timeframe.', 'The pound fell against the dollar and euro on Friday, pausing its recent upward trend, in a move analysts said was likely to be a temporary retracement.', 'Sterling has gained around 1.6 per cent so far this year against the dollar and 4 per cent versus the euro.'], 'Commodities': ['“Platinum and palladium have surged in recent weeks as mine supply problems and the resulting lowering of production guidance by Norilsk are likely to see the supply-demand conditions become even tighter than previously projected in 2021,” writes TD Economics head of commodity strategy Bart Melek.', '“As the global economic recovery continues and global pollution standardstighten, the recent mine site disruptions suggest hefty deficits and a path toward $3,000/oz for palladium and $US1,350/oz for platinum over the next twelve months.', '“According to our models, the palladium market should record a massive defect of some 1.16 million oz in 2021 and some 600koz in 2022, with platinum showing a deficit of 250koz and 16koz over the same period. Traders should also expect very robust jumps in lease rates, as the front end of these markets tighten up.”', 'Stephen Innes from Axi writes, “The oil market is searching for answers, with analysts linking the oil price collapse to slow European recovery due to lockdowns and slow vaccine rollouts. Neither a new nor compelling argument', '“But lower Asian pricing for Middle East crude and higher Chinese imports for Iranian supply are prime culprits. As is the general cross-asset risk-off tone, which is not helping matters', '“But the reality is we are still ways away from a full demand recovery, and it’s record levels of withdrawn production capacity that is the main prop for the oil market. So having crested $US70/bbl on sentiment alone, prices were always vulnerable to a pull-back.”'], 'Australian sharemarket': ['The ASX sealed its first five-day loss in three weeks, dragged down by iron ore miners and energy companies.', 'The S&P/ASX 200 index declined 37.7 points, or 0.6 per cent, to 6708.2, for a weekly loss of 0.9 per cent.', 'The weak performance for the ASX came after US shares ended mostly lower on Thursday, with the Nasdaq dropping almost 2 per cent after tech stocks were hit by renewed inflation fears.', 'The Federal Reserve kept policy on hold and indicated rate increases were not expected until 2024 at the earliest, lifting long-dated Treasury yields.', 'The Reserve Bank of Australia made similar comments on policy on Tuesday when it released the minutes of its latest policy-setting meeting.']}

text: {'heading': ['Australian shares are set to drop as markets reversed moves and treasury yields hit new peaks.', 'The S&P 500 receded from a record high while the Nasdaq shed more than 1 per cent as a spike in U.S. bond yields accelerated a move out of growth stocks and into companies viewed as likely to outperform as the economy recovers.', 'The Russell 1000 value index, which is heavily comprised of cyclical stocks such as financials and energy, added about 0.2 per cent while the Russell 1000 growth index, which includes technology stocks, dropped about 1.4 per cent.', 'That rotation helped lift the Dow Jones Industrial Average to an intraday record high, led by UnitedHealth Group and Goldman Sachs Group, both up more than 2 per cent.', 'The yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasuries crossed 1.75 per cent to hit a 14-month high a day after the Fed projected the strongest growth in nearly 40 years', '“The renewed sell-off in the Treasury market since the conclusion of yesterday’s FOMC meeting may seem hard to square with the message that monetary policy is likely to remain very loose for a long time yet despite stellar economic growth and a substantial pick-up in inflation this year,” writes John Higgins from Capital Economics.', '“One possibility is that it reflects a growing view that the flipside of this message – which seems consistent with the central bank’s revised FAIT framework – will be tighter policy down the road than would otherwise have been required to bring inflation back down towards the Committee’s target.', '“This is apparent when we look under the hood of the Treasury market. Whereas the implied real yields of government bonds with five years or less to maturity have fallen since the start of this year, those of longer-dated ones have risen sharply.”', 'The number of Americans seeking unemployment benefits rose last week to 770,000, a sign that layoffs remain high even as much of the US economy is steadily recovering from the coronavirus recession.', 'The report from the US Labour Department showed that jobless claims climbed from 725,000 the week before. The numbers have dropped sharply since the depths of the recession last spring but still show that employers in some industries continue to lay off workers. title: ASX futures fluctuate as Fed leaves rates unchanged
summary: Australian shares are set for an uncertain open as bond yields fell from earlier peaks. As expected, the Federal Reserve has made no changes in its QE program.
text: {'heading': ['Australian shares are set for an uncertain open as the Federal Reserve made no changes to monetary policy, leaving interest rates in the 0.0 per cent to 0.25 per cent range. ASX futures were flat at 6.14am AEDT after earlier being up, then down.', 'The S&P 500 and the Nasdaq trimmed earlier losses after the Fed statement. Bond yields fell back from earlier peaks after the US/German 10-year yield gap reached a 13-month high.', 'The US Federal Reserve foresees the economy accelerating quickly this year but still expects to keep its benchmark interest rate pinned near zero through 2023, despite concerns in financial markets about potential higher inflation.', 'The Fed also said that it foresees the economy growing at a 6.5 per cent pace this year, up from a previous projection in December of 4.2 per cent. It also expects inflation to reach 2.4 per cent in 2021, above its target of 2 per cent, but expects inflation to fall back to around 2 per cent in 2022.', 'Markets had focused on the Fed’s so-called “dot plot,” which shows the outlook for its policy rate. While some economists expect this will show one rate hike for 2023 versus none in December, an unchanged median dot for that year could be seen as Fed pushback against the recent bond market sell-off.', '“I think the dots here - given that the median expectation is still after 2023 of a rate hike - I think it will actually act to anchor rate expectations,” Tiffany Wilding, Pimco US economist, told Bloomberg in the wake of the decision.', 'Anu Gaggar, senior global investment analyst for Commonwealth Financial Network, called the meeting critical and inconsequential at the same time.', '“What the market was laser focused on was where the infamous dots plotted, particularly for the latter half of 2023. In the December meeting, the vast majority of dots were pinned to the floor. That remained the case in this meeting as well but there were more members that plotted hikes in 2022 and two dots were plotted above 1 per cent in 2023,” she said.', '“Fed officials acknowledged the improving economic outlook and updated GDP growth expectations to 6.5 per cent for 2021 before cooling off in later years. This is quite an improvement from the median expectation of a 4.2 per cent growth expected in December. This, however, was already baked in by the markets. Inflation expectations moved higher as well, to 2.2 per cent. There was no mention of any intention for Operation Twist.', '“Many on the Street were looking for a hawkish Fed, in so far as dots at least. With the 2023 median plot still hugging the floor, stocks and bonds are rising again. This is like a Goldilocks market – strong economic growth, moderately higher inflation, rebounding earnings, and very easy monetary conditions.”', 'Wells Fargo & Co. chief Charlie Scharf says US consumer spending is likely to be the strongest in 70 years over the next two quarters as Americans splash out $US1.7 trillion in excess savings.', '“Consumer demand is extremely high - over the last couple of weeks we, like others, have seen material increases in consumer spend, and that’s before the stimulus checks have arrived,” Scharf said in an interview on Bloomberg Television.', 'Stimulus deposits are arriving in Americans’ bank accounts starting today. “We’re really bullish in terms of what the third and fourth quarters could look like.”', 'This week also marks the one-year anniversary since Wall Street turned bullish. What’s in store for the next year? “The good news is previous bull markets have never been lower during the second year of their existence,” according to LPL Financial chief market strategist Ryan Detrick. “Although it won’t be an easy ride, investors need to remember that history is on the bulls’ side, as this bull market is still just an infant and continued gains are quite likely.”'], "Today's agenda": ['Local: Labour force February data; title: ASX futures point to lower open, Wall St extends slide
summary: It was a volatile day of trading in New York with the Dow moving in a 900-point range and the US 10-year yield rising back through 1.5 per cent.
text: {'heading': ['Australian shares are poised to open lower, with futures mimicking a volatile trading session on Wall Street where the Dow tumbled and the Nasdaq flirted with a correction.', 'ASX futures were down 17 points or 0.3 per cent to 6736 at about 8am AEDT; they traded in a 90-point range overnight. The currency slid 0.7 per cent; the Bloomberg dollar spot index leapt 0.7 per cent.', 'The market moves centred on trading before and after Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell spoke on a webinar. Investors hoping that Mr Powell would signal plans for more aggressive Fed action were disappointed.', 'Mr Powell basic message: the Fed will continue to do what’s necessary to keep the US economy on its recovery track. And he reaffirmed the Fed is not particularly concerned about inflation.', 'The yield on the US 10-year note was 6 basis points higher to 1.54 per cent at 4.11pm in New York; it had been little changed before Mr Powell began speaking.', '“The Fed will eventually have to address the problems at both the short and long end of the curve, but that might not happen until the 10-year yield rallies another 15 basis points higher,” Oanda’s Edward Moya said in a note.', 'Mr Moya said “calls for Operation Twist, or the Fed’s maturity extension program will grow over the coming weeks. Operation twist sells short dated securities and buys long-dated securities in a reserve neutral way. This would help alleviate negative concerns at the front end and skyrocketing moves at the back end.”', 'The 10 -year US yield has risen 40 basis points this past month, and 49 points the past year, highlighting the sudden widening.', 'TD Securities said Mr Powell “disappointed sky-high market expectations”, allowing rates to continue selling off. “With the Chair not pushing back on the selloff in rates, we expect Treasury yields to continue moving higher in the near-term as market optimism persists. Treasuries will also react to payrolls, with a strong reading potentially exacerbating the selloff.”', 'NAB head of FX strategy Ray Attrill said Australian government bond traders and investors can expect more volatility on Friday too. “Volatility seen in local interest rate markets yesterday with another large increase in long-term rates and government bond yields has set the scene for a choppy market again today if overnight developments are any guide.', '“The market was seemingly disappointed by the RBA’s decision to revert to a $2 billion purchase of Australian government bonds under its QE programme, after it upsized its purchase amount to $4 billion earlier in the week.”', 'Mr Attrill also said the RBA passed up the opportunity to buy 3-year bonds under its Yield Curve Control policy.', 'As for equities, it was a wild session. The Dow was up near 200 points in morning trade. After Mr Powell spoke, the index shed 900 points. At the close it had pared its loss to 346 points or 1.1 per cent. The VIX leapt 7.1 per cent to 28.55; it briefly topped 30.', 'The S&P 500 was 1.3 per cent lower at 4pm; the Nasdaq slid 2.1 per cent, and in the process wiped out its year-to-date gain. Energy was up 2.5 per cent, bolstered by oil’s surge on reports of a further month extension in production cuts principally by Saudi Arabia.', 'Tesla tumbled 4.9 per cent even as one of its most bullish watchers encouraged investors to keep the faith. Bitcoin was down 5.2 per cent at about $US48,200 near 8.20am AEDT.', 'ARK Innovation ETF, run by Cathie Wood, is also getting hit; its top holding is Tesla. The ETF was 5.3 per cent lower in New York, erasing all of its 2021 gains.', 'The NYSE Fang + Index shed 2.7 per cent. Apple, Netflix and Microsoft were lower.', '“The US stock market has experienced a massive run-up after bottoming last spring,” First Trust’s Brian Wesbury said in a tweet.” To see it pull back is not a surprise, but we maintain our year-end target of 4200 for the S&P 500. Fed money printing and excessive spending are a long-term problem, not a short-term one.”', 'In London, Rio Tinto and BHP Group shed 7.7pc and 5.8pc, respectively, as they traded ex-dividend. In New York, Rio was down 5.7 per cent and BHP was 3.8 per cent lower.', 'The spot price of iron ore advanced 0.9 per cent to $US177.98 a tonne, according to Fastmarkets MB. It also said its index for iron ore 65 per cent iron Brazil-origin fines, cfr Qingdao rose to a record at $US202.90 a tonne.', 'In LME trading, nickel, which reached a seven-year high of $US20,110 last week, fell to $US16,100 a tonne, down 7.6pc for its biggest one-day loss since 2016.', 'Copper which hit a 10-year high of $US9617 a tonne last week, was down 3pc at $US8833 at 1740 GMT after falling as low as $US8654.50.', 'It has been a long time coming,” said Saxo Bank analyst Ole Hansen, pointing to a huge influx of speculative investment that drove all industrial metals to multi-year highs.', '“The trigger was the nickel sell-off. title: ASX to slip, tech slide hits S&P 500, Nasdaq
summary: Australian shares appear poised for a modest opening loss. US stocks were mostly lower amid renewed selling of the mega techs. Bitcoin tops $US51,000.

title: ASX to edge higher, Wall St consolidates
summary: Australian shares are set to rise at the open, though gains could be checked as US stocks reset lower after the previous session’s surge. $A higher.
text: {'heading': ['Australian shares are set to edge modestly higher at the open. Wall Street eased after surging higher the previous session.', 'ASX futures were up 16 points or 0.2 per cent to 6738 near 8am AEDT. The currency rose 0.7 per cent. The yield on the US 10-year note slipped 2 basis points to 1.40 per cent.', 'Today’s GDP data could further bolster the Aussie.', 'The data could be the catalyst to propel the $A higher again, according to Steven Dooley, currency strategist at Western Union Business Solutions.', '“Last quarter’s GDP result beat expectations, and we expect that trend to continue,” Mr Dooley said. “A better-than-expected result from exports along with a strong showing from retail could see the quarterly result as high as 3.0pc.”', 'Mr Dooley said he expects last week’s $A retreat to be temporary. “Our June 2021 target is US82¢ and our December 2021 is US84¢. We have raised our targets as commodity prices have increased.”', 'On Wall Street, all three major benchmarks closed down as an early afternoon reprieve proved fleeting. Facebook, Amazon and Microsoft each closed at least 1.3 per cent lower. title: ASX to rise, Dow up 600 points, Nasdaq surges
summary: Australian shares are to rise near 1pc at the open as techs powered Wall Street higher. Nasdaq up 3pc. RBA policy meeting on agenda. $A leaps.
text: {'heading': ['Australian shares are poised to extend Monday’s advance, as equities advanced across Europe and on Wall Street.', 'ASX futures were up 60 points or 0.9 per cent to 6817 near 8am AEDT. title: ASX to bounce, bond selloff eases
